awd_titl_txt: Investigating the scales of sustainability in groundwater extraction
awd_abstract_narration:
Katherine H. Markovich has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education plans at the University of Arizona. The key goal of the research is to investigate the relationship of groundwater age and sustainability. The two have often been conflated, but there has yet to be a mechanistic study linking the distributions of groundwater age encountered in a pumping well with the sustainability of extracting water from that well. This work will bring together stakeholders in Tucson such as water managers, native communities, urban residents, and industry representatives to establish mutually agreed upon parameters for groundwater sustainability, such as acceptable spatial and temporal scale of overdraft. The results of this stakeholder engagement will be explored using a combination of age tracers for residence time estimation and integrated hydrologic modeling. The study is important in linking groundwater age to sustainability using advanced modeling and age-dating techniques, as well as to advance national health and welfare, since access to clean water is paramount for the prosperity of communities in semi-arid and arid regions of the United States. 

Multiple age tracers will be linked with a sophisticated integrated hydrologic model to explore the full spatial and temporal scales of flow path and storage response to groundwater extraction, using the Tucson regional aquifer system as a case study. Extraction wells will be sampled for common age-dating tracers (Tritium-Helium and Carbon-13) to estimate the fraction of young and old water encountered in Tucson extraction wells, respectively, using a novel tracer (Argon-39) to estimate the intermediate age fraction. The integration of these three tracers will reveal a more complete distribution of flow paths contributing to a well, and thus provide insight as to the recharge and hydrogeologic characteristics of the regional aquifer system. These results will be used to validate an integrated hydrologic model (ParFlow-CLM) of the Tucson area via a particle tracking code (EcoSLIM). This step will result in a model that captures the dominant flow systems contributing to Tucson extraction wells. The posterior model will then be used to explore the relationship between groundwater age and sustainability, and project this relationship forward under climate change and population growth scenarios.  This result will fill in the gaps in our understanding of flow path distributions to wells using non-overlapping age tracers and link those results to a sophisticated regional aquifer model that includes the upland recharge and contributing areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Groundwater is a critically important resource for populations in the arid and semi-arid western US. The large volumes of good quality water in the subsurface, referred to as aquifers, augment surface supplies such as rivers and reservoirs, and act as buffers during dry periods when surface supplies dwindle. It is not an infinite resource; however, and therefore extraction of groundwater should aim to be as sustainable as possible to ensure this critical resource continues to be available.

While the volumes extracted from groundwater aquifers can be estimated, the volumes of water getting added to aquifers each year, referred to as recharge, are much more difficult to quantify. The balance between extraction and recharge is a key piece to sustainable management, especially given that climate change is altering the amount of timing of recharge to aquifers.

This project focused on understanding the time scales and spatial scales of recharge to characterize and quantify it, using the aquifer beneath Tucson, AZ as a case study. The time scales were investigated through groundwater age dating, where chemical components dissolved in the groundwater give information on when that parcel of water first made it into the aquifer. Old water indicates longer pathways and/or slower movement in the subsurface and young water indicates short pathways and/or fast movement. In Tucson, the main options for recharge that correspond to old and young include water that travels through the mountains themselves to enter the sandy aquifer that sits between the mountain ranges (old) and water that seeps into the sandy aquifer from the ephemeral washes that emanate from the mountains during snowmelt and monsoon rains. Here, understanding the age of water encountered in extraction wells in Tucson can tell us where that water came from and how much of it enters each year.

Ultimately this project found that the vast majority of recharge to the aquifer beneath Tucson comes from the ephemeral washes. This quantity is large compared to current extraction rates but varies quite a lot year to year depending on how much snow falls in the mountains. The project itself advanced knowledge in the field of groundwater hydrology by demonstrating how groundwater age combined with computer models spanning the mountains and valley can tell us where and how much recharge is occurring, and how that recharge might change in a warmer future.

This project benefitted society primarily through mentorship and training of postdocs and graduate students to contribute to and broaden participation of underrepresented monitories, specifically LGBTQ, Asian, Latinx, and female scientists, in the geoscience workforce. An additional outcome of the project that benefitted society was the continued investment in a strong partnership with the local water utility that is responsible for sustainability managing groundwater resources. This partnership is critical for knowledge transfer and translating science to action, which will ultimately benefit all end users of the water utility.

The tangible outcomes of the project include four peer-reviewed publications in high impact journals with another in preparation, two of which have earned the award for Most Downloaded Paper from Water Resources Research, one of which was a student-led paper, and one which was featured in the American Geophysical Union science news magazine, Eos. During the lifetime of the award, the project PI gave 5 invited talks ranging from departmental seminars, local chapters of scientific societies, and major conferences. And finally, the project inspired a MS and PhD thesis topic at the host institution.
